isis.stitle: CF 500, CF 600 Cooling System - Cooling System - Diagnosis and Testing

warning.para: Do not unscrew the coolant pressure relief cap while the engine is operating or hot. The cooling system is under pressure; steam and hot liquid can come out forcefully when the cap is loosened slightly. Failure to follow these instructions may result in personal injury.

caution.para: Check the coolant level, engine oil and transmission fluid. Top off the coolant if needed. If there is engine coolant in the engine oil or transmission fluid, the cause must be corrected and oil/fluid changed or major component damage can occur.
Always fill the cooling system with the same coolant that is present in the system. Do not mix coolant types.

step1.para: Verify the customer concern by operating the engine to duplicate the condition.
Inspect to determine if any of the following mechanical or electrical concerns apply.

item.para: Restricted airflow through the radiator cooling fins

step1.para: If the inspection reveals an obvious concern that can be readily identified, repair it as necessary.

item.para: If the engine coolant appearance is acceptable, test the engine coolant freezing point range. The freezing point should be in the range -46°C to -23°C (-50°F to -10°F). If the vehicle is driven in cold climates lower than -37°C (-34°F), it may be necessary to increase the coolant concentration to get adequate freeze protection.
Adjust coolant range and level if necessary:
If coolant is low, add specified coolant mixture only.
If the engine coolant tests too weak, add straight engine coolant until the readings are within acceptable levels.
If the engine coolant tests strong, remove some of the engine coolant and add distilled water until the readings are within acceptable levels.

step1.para: If the concern remains after the inspection, determine the symptom(s). GO to Symptom Chart.

table.title: Engine Control Module (ECM) Diagnostic Trouble Code

entry.para: Engine coolant temperature unable to reach commanded set point
Engine coolant temperature above warning level
Engine coolant temperature above critical level
Power reduced - matched to cooling system performance

item.para: Insufficient water or coolant in coolant mixture.

entry.para: The engine does not reach normal operating temperature
The block heater does not operate correctly

item.para: CHECK the resistance of all 3 circuits in the power cable. If any circuit measures greater than 5 ohms, INSTALL a new power cable.
CHECK the resistance of the block heater. If it does not measure between 12.5 and 17.0 ohms, INSTALL a new block heater.

table.title: PINPOINT TEST A: LOSS OF COOLANT

para.emph: A1 CHECK THE ENGINE COOLANT LEVEL

note.para: Allow the engine to cool before checking the engine coolant level.

warning.para: Do not unscrew the coolant pressure relief cap while the engine is operating or hot. The cooling system is under pressure; steam and hot liquid can release forcefully when the cap is loosened slightly. Failure to follow these instructions may result in personal injury.

item.para: Visually check the engine coolant level at the coolant reservoir.

para.emph: Is the engine coolant level within specification?

entry.para: REFILL the engine coolant as necessary. GO to A2.

para.emph: A2 CHECK THE COOLANT RESERVOIR PRESSURE RELIEF CAP

warning.para: Do not unscrew the coolant pressure relief cap while the engine is operating or hot. The cooling system is under pressure; steam and hot liquid can release forcefully when the cap is loosened slightly. Failure to follow these instructions may result in personal injury.

item.para: Inspect the pressure relief cap for foreign material between the sealing gasket and the diaphragm.

para.emph: Is the pressure relief cap OK?

entry.para: CLEAN or INSTALL a new pressure relief cap. TEST the system for normal operation. GO to A3.

para.emph: A3 CHECK THE ENGINE COOLANT FOR AN INTERNAL LEAK

warning.para: Do not unscrew the coolant pressure relief cap while the engine is operating or hot. The cooling system is under pressure; steam and hot liquid can release forcefully when the cap is loosened slightly. Failure to follow these instructions may result in personal injury.

item.para: Inspect the engine coolant in the coolant reservoir for signs of transmission fluid or engine oil.

para.emph: Is oil or transmission fluid evident in the coolant?

entry.para: If engine oil is evident, GO to EGES-305, Engine Diagnostics Manual. If transmission fluid is evident, REPAIR or INSTALL a new radiator as necessary.
REFILL the engine coolant as necessary. GO to A4.

para.emph: A4 CHECK THE ENGINE AND THE TRANSMISSION FOR COOLANT

item.para: Remove the oil level and transmission fluid level indicators.

para.emph: Is coolant evident in the oil/fluid?

entry.para: If coolant is in the engine, GO to EGES-305, Engine Diagnostics Manual. If coolant is in the transmission, INSTALL a new radiator.
REFILL the engine coolant as necessary. GO to A5.

para.emph: A5 PRESSURE TEST THE ENGINE COOLING SYSTEM

item.para: Pressure test the engine cooling system.

para.emph: Does the engine cooling system leak?

entry.para: REPAIR or INSTALL new components. TEST the system for normal operation.
The cooling system is operational. GO to Symptom Chart.

table.title: PINPOINT TEST B: THE ENGINE OVERHEATS

para.emph: B1 CHECK THE ENGINE COOLANT LEVEL

note.para: If the engine is hot, allow the engine to cool before proceeding.

warning.para: Do not unscrew the coolant pressure relief cap while the engine is operating or hot. The cooling system is under pressure; steam and hot liquid can release forcefully when the cap is loosened slightly. Failure to follow these instructions may result in personal injury.

item.para: Check the engine coolant level at the coolant reservoir.

entry.para: REFILL the engine coolant at the coolant reservoir. GO to Pinpoint Test A.

item.para: Check the coolant for contaminants such as rust, corrosion or discoloration.

entry.para: FLUSH the engine cooling system. TEST the system for normal operation.

para.emph: B3 CHECK FOR AN AIRFLOW OBSTRUCTION

item.para: Inspect the A/C condenser core, radiator and the charge-air-cooler, for obstructions such as leaves or dirt.

entry.para: REMOVE the obstruction. CLEAN the A/C condenser core, charge-air-cooler and radiator. TEST the system for normal operation.

para.emph: B4 CHECK THE COOLANT THERMOSTAT OPERATION

item.para: Drive for 20 minutes in 2nd gear to open the thermostat.
Feel the inlet heater hose and the underside of the upper radiator hose.

para.emph: Are the upper radiator hose and the inlet heater hoses cold?

entry.para: INSTALL a new coolant thermostat. TEST the system for normal operation.

para.emph: B5 CHECK THE COOLING FAN OPERATION

item.para: Carry out the cooling fan component tests. Refer to Fan Clutch Test in this section.

para.emph: Is the cooling fan operation OK?

entry.para: REFER to EGES-305, Engine Diagnostics Manual for diagnosis and testing of the engine.
INSTALL new fan components as necessary. TEST the system for normal operation.

table.title: PINPOINT TEST C: THE ENGINE DOES NOT REACH NORMAL OPERATING TEMPERATURE

item.para: Drive for 20 minutes in 2nd gear to open the thermostat.
Feel the inlet heater hose and the underside of the upper radiator hose.

para.emph: Are the upper radiator hose and the inlet heater hose cold?

entry.para: INSTALL a new coolant thermostat. TEST the system for normal operation.
REFER to Instrument Cluster in S08307 for diagnosis and testing of the engine coolant temperature gauge.

svcsubproc.title: Component Tests - Thermostat - Coolant
svcsubproc.para: A new coolant thermostat should be installed only after the following electrical and mechanical tests have been carried out.

caution.para: Always vent the exhaust to the outside when carrying out this test.

note.para: The electrical thermostat test is most accurate if carried out indoors at less than 37.8°C (100°F) ambient air. This test may be carried out with the engine warm or cold.

step1.para: Check the engine coolant level. Fill as needed.
A diagnostic tool may be used to monitor the engine coolant temperature (ECT).

note.para: Running this test with the vehicle in gear or with the A/C compressor clutch engaged (running) will cause incorrect diagnosis.

step1.para: Place the transmission in PARK (P) or NEUTRAL (N).

Start the engine and allow the engine to idle throughout this test. Allow the engine to run for 2 minutes, then record the engine coolant temperature (ECT) voltage. Record the ECT sensor voltage every 60 seconds. When the ECT sensor voltage trend changes direction or only changes slightly (0.03 volt or less) from the previous reading, record this as the thermostat opening voltage. Use the voltage and corresponding coolant temperature chart listed below.
If the thermostat opening voltage is greater than 0.75 volts which corresponds to a coolant temperature of less than 82°C (180°F), install a new coolant thermostat.

If the thermostat opening voltage is less than 0.75 volts which corresponds to a temperature of greater than 82°C (180°F), the coolant thermostat is good, a new thermostat should not be installed. GO to Symptom Chart for further instructions.

Check the coolant thermostat for seating. Hold the coolant thermostat up to a lighted background. Leakage of light around the thermostat valve at room temperature indicates that a new coolant thermostat should be installed. Some coolant thermostats have a small leakage notch at one location on the perimeter of the thermostat valve, which is considered normal.
Immerse the coolant thermostat in a boiling antifreeze and water mixture.
See the General Specifications chart for coolant thermostat opening temperatures.

svcsubproc.title: Component Tests - Radiator Leak Test, Removed From the Vehicle

caution.para: Never leak test an aluminum radiator in the same water that copper/brass radiators are tested in. Flux and caustic cleaners may be present in the cleaning tank and they will damage aluminum radiators.

note.para: Always install plugs in the oil cooler fittings before leak-testing or cleaning any radiator.
Clean the radiator before leak-testing to avoid contamination of the tank.

step1.para: Leak test the radiator in clean water with 138 kPa (20 psi) air pressure.

svcsubproc.para: Inspect the fan blade for cracks or missing blades.

step1.para: Inspect the fan clutch for excessive wobble or free play at the mounting shaft.

Run the engine at 2,000 rpm for 5 minutes to disengage the fan clutch. Shut off the engine and spin the fan blade by hand. A light resistance should be felt. No resistance or very high resistance indicates an unserviceable fan clutch.
If any of the above conditions exists, install a new fan clutch. For additional information, refer to Cooling Fan in this section.
